headline: CNN Special Reports
subHeadline: The Murdaugh Murders: A Twisted Tale of Power and Money. Aired 12-1a ET

utterances.speaker: ALEX MURDAUGH, DISGRACED LAWYER
utterances.sentences: I could see his brain on his ...And I ran over to Maggie. Actually, I think I tried to turn Paul over first. RANDI KAYE, CNN NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT (voice-over):  Alex Murdaugh ...

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Double-murder mystery.KAYE (voice-over):  -- on trial.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Alex Murdaugh --KAYE (voice-over):  -- accused of killing his wife and son.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The evidence will show that he was there.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: He would be covered in blood.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: There was no blood on him that I could see.KAYE (voice-over):  For the first time, those closely tied to this shocking story sit down together. MIKE HEMLEPP, SANDY SMITH'S ATTORNEY:  Every lawyer at this table is on trial. JORDAN JINKS, ALEX MURDAUGH'S FRIEND:  It's a good feeling to be connected to the power.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Until it comes back to bite you.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Powerful family, series of unsolved killings --

utterances.speaker: ERIC BLAND, ATTORNEY
utterances.sentences: How many families do you know that have five dead bodies in their orbit?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Murdaugh's housekeeper died in 2018, in a slip and fall at Murdaugh's home. GINGER HARRIOTT HADWIN, GLORIA SATTERFIELD'S ATTORNEY

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Nineteen-year-old Stephen Smith was found dead on the side of the road.SANDY SMITH, STEPHEN SMITH'S MOTHER:  I want justice.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Good evening. I'm Randi Kaye.Tonight, for the first time, Alex Murdaugh's victims and alleged victims, their lawyers and local reporters, who, for years, have been covering every detail of this case, come together to talk about the man who changed their lives forever and the mystery that has shaken this community.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: You're all brought together by really one man. But some of you, you do know each other, right, from --

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: JINKS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Our families worked together or went to school together.

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: Were together, yes.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: There's always a connection.

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: Always a connection some way, yes.

utterances.speaker: JINKS
utterances.sentences: My father owned a grocery store for 54 years, which, everyone came to that grocery store. That's what put me in the middle, to be able to know everyone.

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: We call him JJ.(LAUGHTER) KAYE (voice-over):  Jordan Jinks, Ginger Harriott and Sandy Smith grew up in the rural county of Hampton, South Carolina. Less than 3,000 people live in the town of Hampton.

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: One thing about Hampton also, I mean, genuine people live there.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Like all your friends' children would come to your house. And they call you mom.

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: Right.KAYE (voice-over):  Hampton is also the hometown of Alex Murdaugh.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: What was Alex Murdaugh like as a young boy?

utterances.speaker: JINKS
utterances.sentences: Kind of rough but typical friend. I mean, we were both interested in hunting and fishing and stuff like that.

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: We were kids. I mean, we went all to school together. So I just thought he was Alex. He was, you know, loud and he was just Alex.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Alex, he just seemed arrogant and conceited and like I'm better than you.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: You stayed friendly or in touch with him over the years?

utterances.speaker: JINKS
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. I got wedding gifts from him. I gave him gifts. I went out of town and stuff he liked, I knew it, I brought it back. I mean, we were friends. I trusted him.KAYE (voice-over):  Alex Murdaugh wasn't just a resident of Hampton; Alex's great grandfather, grandfather and father, Randolph Murdaugh III, had all been the county's district attorneys or what they call solicitors.

utterances.speaker: MANDY MATNEY, JOURNALIST
utterances.sentences: Being a solicitor in South Carolina is one of the most powerful positions in our legal system.KAYE (voice-over):  Mandy Matney, John Monk and Liz Farrell are all local journalists.

utterances.speaker: LIZ FARRELL, JOURNALIST
utterances.sentences: People do have trouble finding lawyers here because of the way the legal system works. You have to be careful about who you hire sometimes because of who they might be associated with.KAYE (voice-over):  Over a century ago, Alex's great grandfather, a solicitor, also started a local law firm, formerly called Pieters, Murdaugh, Parker, Eltzroth and Detrick or PMPED for short. JOHN MONK, REPORTER, "THE STATE":  The firm is a plaintiffs' law firm, which means it specializes in wrongful deaths, medical malpractice, suing big corporations on behalf of victims. KAYE (voice-over):  Monk has been reporting in South Carolina for nearly 50 years.

utterances.speaker: MONK
utterances.sentences: -- juries that had the reputation of siding with them in a big way.

utterances.speaker: MATNEY
utterances.sentences: Something that people don't understand about PMPED and their control over Hampton County, most names that I've looked up in the Hampton County public index, so many of them have lawsuits connected to PMPED.Everybody has a cousin who's gotten a lot of money from calling PMPED and them handling a car accident, for instance. I've heard that a million times. KAYE:  Yes, it created a loyalty.

utterances.speaker: MATNEY
utterances.sentences: Yes, it creates a loyalty and it creates a -- like a culture of silence basically.

utterances.speaker: FARRELL
utterances.sentences: Yes, for sure.KAYE (voice-over):  Alex Murdaugh, a lawyer himself, worked at his family's law firm, PMPED, since he graduated law school back in 1994. Mike Hemlepp, Justin Bamberg, Joe McCulloch and Eric Bland are all local litigators.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: All four of you graduated from the University of South Carolina School of Law, correct?

utterances.speaker: JOE MCCULLOCH, SOUTH CAROLINA ATTORNEY
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Because Alex Murdaugh also graduated from the same school.

utterances.speaker: HEMLEPP
utterances.sentences: Randy and I graduated together.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: His brother?

utterances.speaker: HEMLEPP
utterances.sentences: Yes, his brother.

utterances.speaker: JUSTIN BAMBERG, ATTORNEY
utterances.sentences: Growing up, the Murdaughs, even over in Bamberg County, you know, people knew who they were.

utterances.speaker: MCCULLOCH
utterances.sentences: Randy, I have stories I will tell you. I was talking to a lawyer here in town, who said his old law partner, who was a big political figure here in town, got a call one day from old Buster.KAYE (voice-over):  Buster is the nickname of Alex Murdaugh's grandfather, a solicitor who served for 46 years.

utterances.speaker: MCCULLOCH
utterances.sentences: Buster said, Counselor, I know you can help me out here. My boy has gotten into some trouble. And he needs to be gotten out of it. And I know you can handle it.And so the lawyer jumped right on it and, within an hour, he'd made the calls, like we could do in the good old days and make problems go away. And he called Buster back and he said, Solicitor, I got it taken care of. It's all gone. He said, Well, what do I owe you? He said, Solicitor, I don't need to be paid. You know, this is a favor. And he said, Buster then said to him, well, you know, Counselor, if you ever need to kill a man, you bring him to Hampton County. And whether that was true or false, maybe a joke that was the reputation and that is what that community has dealt with for decades.

utterances.speaker: JINKS
utterances.sentences: That law firm did a great deal for the county residents. But it doesn't give that law firm the right to have so much power to suppress law enforcement. You know --

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: And that's what you think is going on here?

utterances.speaker: JINKS
utterances.sentences: Yes. And if the Murdaugh family did something wrong, they are guilty, Murdaughs or not. We ain't playing on a level playing field when it comes to Hampton County and the Murdaugh family.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: Your status in an environment, a town, it should not exclude you from the law.

utterances.speaker: JINKS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: You should -- if you do wrong, you should be punished like anyone else.

utterances.speaker: JINKS
utterances.sentences: You know, yes, I like being connected to the power for 50 years. I could pick up the phone if somebody is bothering me.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Until it comes back to bite you?

utterances.speaker: JINKS
utterances.sentences: Exactly.KAYE (voice-over):  PMPED, now named Parker Law, did not respond to CNN's request for comment.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: The state grand jury has indicted Murdaugh on about 90 charges or so. In terms of schemes to defraud victims totaling nearly $8.8 million or so, he's also been indicted, as you know, on the two counts of murder in connection with the deaths of his wife and son.As lawyers practicing for quite some time in this state, what do you make of that?

utterances.speaker: BLAND
utterances.sentences: Proud, proud of our legal system, proud of our attorney general, proud of our judges. I mean --

utterances.speaker: HEMLEPP
utterances.sentences: I want to add something.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HEMLEPP
utterances.sentences: I am not proud. I am angry. I'm very angry.You asked how we feel about this? Alex threw all of us under the bus. The entire world is looking at South Carolina. And every lawyer at this table is on trial because of greed and avarice. I represent the family of a 19- year-old kid, who was poor, who was brutally murdered and left on the side of the road. And who gave a crap about that in 2015? KAYE (voice-over):  When we return --

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: They beat him to death.

utterances.speaker: MCCULLOCH
utterances.sentences: Now we know, there's missing evidence.KAYE (voice-over):  A look inside the five mysterious deaths.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Paul (ph) recorded a video. The evidence will show that he was there.KAYE (voice-over):  All circling Alex's orbit.

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: We grew up close.KAYE (voice-over):  Ginger is Gloria's younger sister.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: How close was Gloria to the --

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: Oh, very much. She baby-sat for them before she started doing the housekeeping. Paul was about 13 months old. And he was just starting to walk. She would wear skirts all the time and he would walk around and hold her skirt while she was doing the housework and stuff. She pretty much raised him, him and Buster.She thought the world of Maggie.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Double murder mystery. This morning, investigators trying to find who killed two members of one of South Carolina's most prominent legal families.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: What about the murder of Maggie and Paul?What is it that has surprised you the most? What still shocks you?

utterances.speaker: MATNEY
utterances.sentences: Liz was one of the first people that called me that morning. And speechless, absolutely, was the word.

utterances.speaker: FARRELL
utterances.sentences: Unbelievable. Unbelievable. I started making calls because I was worried that, right from that moment, that, already, this is being covered up.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: The Colleton County coroner's office tells us preliminary results show both died from gunshot wounds.

utterances.speaker: MONK
utterances.sentences: There were many different thoughts that filled my mind.

utterances.speaker: MATNEY
utterances.sentences: The phone has kept me up at night.What is with Maggie's phone? How does that puzzle piece fit into all of this?

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: John, you had the first story that revealed that Maggie's cellphone had been found in the woods?

utterances.speaker: MONK
utterances.sentences: Right, about a half a mile away from the Moselle Estate.KAYE (voice-over):  Moselle is what they called the 1,700-acre hunting property where the Murdaughs had a home.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: The feeling in the community, whoever killed the Murdaughs didn't end up here by accident or randomly.

utterances.speaker: MCCULLOCH
utterances.sentences: Crimes like this that don't involve robbery, statistically, come back to a family member.

utterances.speaker: BLAND
utterances.sentences: Passionate crime.

utterances.speaker: MCCULLOCH
utterances.sentences: They were killed in a hail of bullets, each of them. And so that does suggest the passion that you mentioned.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Hampton County 9-1-1.What's your emergency? A. MURDAUGH:  This is Alex Murdaugh.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: He says he showed up at their property in Moselle and called 9- 1-1 and found his wife and son bleeding. He reported them outside the dog kennels.

utterances.speaker: BAMBERG
utterances.sentences: The number one thing that stood out to me was the first time hearing the 9-1-1 call. The moment you call 9-1-1 and hit send on your phone, even though no one has answered and it's just ringing, it's recording on the dispatch end.And the phone is dead silent. And you can hear the dogs barking in the background. And as soon as dispatch answers, it's this panicked Alex.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Hampton County 9-1-1, what's your emergency?A. MURDAUGH:  This is Alex Murdaugh.

utterances.speaker: BAMBERG
utterances.sentences: I never knew panic could get cut on and off.

utterances.speaker: MCCULLOCH
utterances.sentences: Let the blubbering begin.A. MURDAUGH:  I need the police and an ambulance immediately. My wife and child have been shot badly.

utterances.speaker: MCCULLOCH
utterances.sentences: That was so weird to me.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: You're saying he would have been panicked even before that, before it started -- before anybody picked up the line.

utterances.speaker: MCCULLOCH
utterances.sentences: That's really perceptive. I hadn't picked up on that.

utterances.speaker: BLAND
utterances.sentences: He would be hyperventilating.A. MURDAUGH:  We had a wonderful marriage, a wonderful relationship.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Any problems in Paul's relationship?A. MURDAUGH:  As good as it could be.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: This is Alex Murdaugh, being interviewed in the investigator's car hours after his wife and son were murdered.A. MURDAUGH:  I mean, I pulled up and I could see him.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes.A. MURDAUGH:  I could see it was ... And I could see his brain on his ... And I ran over to Maggie and -- actually, I think I tried to turn Paul over first. I tried to take their pulse on both of them.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes.A. MURDAUGH:  And, you know, I called 9-1-1 pretty much right away. KAYE (voice-over):  We hear him explain how he says he tried to reach his wife and son with no luck. A. MURDAUGH:  I got up, I called Maggie, didn't get an answer. And I think I texted her. I texted her at 9:08, going to check on him, be right back. And I texted her at 9:47. That must be when I started to come back. I think I called her before that. But let me make sure. I'm pretty sure that I called her, 9:45. And then I tried Paul.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: The unsolved double killings, just one of the many twists and turns deepening questions surrounding this powerful family. HEMLEPPdon't understand about this entire story is somebody may read about it and they watch CNN and learn about it and feel like this happened quickly. It did not. This was a slow burn. It was like there was no bottom to the hole that was being dug.

utterances.speaker: MCCULLOCH
utterances.sentences: He is a guy that embodies the old saying, if you are going through hell, just keep on going.

utterances.speaker: BLAND
utterances.sentences: It's the onion that you keep peeling and you never get to the core.

utterances.speaker: HEMLEPP
utterances.sentences: Right.KAYE (voice-over):  Mike Hemlepp is the attorney for Sandy Smith. Sandy's son, 19-year-old Stephen Smith, was found lying in the middle of a Hampton County road in July of 2015.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: The highway patrol's incident report notes that he suffered from blunt force trauma to the head.KAYE (voice-over):  His death was initially deemed by the South Carolina Law Enforcement Division -- or SLED -- as a hit and run.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Stephen's case was cold for quite some time. And now SLED is taking another look at it because of what they say was something that was discovered after the double murder of Maggie and Paul Murdaugh, which is really interesting.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Yes, because it was like mind blowing. And I have been begging, you know. Nobody ever returned my call.KAYE (voice-over):  Coming up --

utterances.speaker: BLAND
utterances.sentences: You're talking about a young man who's homosexual. You're talking about a small southern town.

utterances.speaker: BAMBERG
utterances.sentences: It's taboo.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: 9-1-1, where's your emergency?MAGGIE MURDAUGH, ALEX MURDAUGH'S WIFE:  My housekeeper has fallen and her head is bleeding. I cannot get her up.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Longtime housekeeper for the Murdaugh family died after suffering some kind of fall at the Murdaugh home.

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: To learn that he used Gloria's death to enrich himself is horrible.(MUSIC PLAYING) (COMMERCIAL BREAK) (MUSIC PLAYING)

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Share a little bit about your son, Stephen.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry y'all missed an opportunity to meet him --(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: -- because he was very vibrant.You could have a bad day and all he had to do was walk in the room and say something and it was like, your mood is gone because you couldn't stop.

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: Laughing or smiling.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: He would light up a room.He had plans and dreams?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Yes. He started at a tech school to become a nurse.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Did you know the Murdaugh family?

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: The Stephen Smith case was reopened by SLED as a result of something that was found at the double murder scene for Maggie and Paul Murdaugh.

utterances.speaker: HEMLEPP
utterances.sentences: So Stephen died and he was found July 7th of 2015. Rumors were everywhere, everywhere. This is a small county. It's impossible that people didn't know what happened. People talk.

utterances.speaker: BAMBERG
utterances.sentences: What the talk has always been was that Stephen had some sort of a relationship with a Murdaugh and that that was going to get out.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: So they took him out?

utterances.speaker: BLAND
utterances.sentences: Think how courageous Stephen was. You're talking about a young man who's homosexual, who isn't hiding it, is very proud of who he is. You're talking about a small Southern town.

utterances.speaker: BAMBERG
utterances.sentences: It's taboo.

utterances.speaker: BLAND
utterances.sentences: It's taboo.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: BLAND
utterances.sentences: And he's wearing it proud. And somebody didn't like it. It clearly had to have been related to his sexuality.Don't you believe, Mike?

utterances.speaker: HEMLEPP
utterances.sentences: A hundred percent, 100 percent. South Carolina and Wyoming are the only two states that have no hate crimes law.

utterances.speaker: BLAND
utterances.sentences: We have no hate crimes law?

utterances.speaker: BAMBERG
utterances.sentences: No. We can't get one passed and we have been trying and begging and fighting.

utterances.speaker: BLAND
utterances.sentences: You are kidding me?

utterances.speaker: BAMBERG
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: What happened to Stephen Smith?

utterances.speaker: HEMLEPP
utterances.sentences: There's so much we don't know. We know some bare bones facts.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Hampton County 9-1-1, what's your emergency?

utterances.speaker: HEMLEPP
utterances.sentences: We know that he was found at 4 o'clock in the morning on Sandy Run Road in Hampton. He was about a mile from his car. He had died of horrific blunt force trauma to his head. His skull was fractured.His wallet was in his car. He had his cell phone. And he was not that far from his father's house, where he lived. His twin sister, Stefanie, was also at home. I was a prosecutor for a long time. But I have prosecuted cases of people having been hit by cars. This is not the scene of a hit and run. There was no debris.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: There was no debris. Lower extremities, nothing was broken and his loosely tied sneakers were still on him, on his feet?

utterances.speaker: HEMLEPP
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BAMBERG
utterances.sentences: Could have been blown off.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: If it was a hit and run.

utterances.speaker: HEMLEPP
utterances.sentences: Every hit and run case I have ever seen, shoes blow off. They did not have their shoes on. A hit and run is extraordinarily violent, extraordinarily violent. He had some abrasions but not significant.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: What do you remember about that night and when you learned what had happened to your son? SMITHKAYE (voice-over):  Joel was Stephen's father.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Stefanie answered.I said, are y'all OK? I heard something happened down the road. They found a body. And she said, Mom, did Stephen spend the night at your house last night? I said, no. And then I knew. I know it was him.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Is that a mother's instinct?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes. Yes, because Stephen was my baby. So we were always close.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: And I know that, soon after, Randy Murdaugh had called.KAYE (voice-over):  Randy is Alex Murdaugh's brother.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: When I was on phone with Joel, he said, let me put you on hold, because Randy Murdaugh is calling. He said, Randy wants to take Stephen's case pro bono.And I was like, what case? Because they said it was a hit and run.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Did you think that call from Randy Murdaugh was strange?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Yes. It made no sense to me.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Yes. And he's --

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: I mean, really, there was no case there yet.

utterances.speaker: JINKS
utterances.sentences: Yes. And you didn't even know it was a case yet.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: And his law office has said that he didn't call -- he didn't know Stephen had died until after the funeral.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Excuse me, but Alex Murdaugh and Randy Murdaugh were standing at the crime scene.ALAYNIA SPOHN, ALEX MURDAUGH'S CLIENT:  Oh, wow.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: They were at the crime scene after Stephen's body was moved.Randy Murdaugh called and asked, was that you that just passed by? I said, yes. He said, I wish you would have stopped so I could have met you.

utterances.speaker: JINKS
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: SPOHN
utterances.sentences: At the crime scene.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: JINKS
utterances.sentences: At the crime scene.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: His office says that he never officered to represent the family in any way.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I don't feel like it's a hit and run. I've looked at the body itself.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: You know, a lot of people seem a little nervous to say the name Murdaugh.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: The lead investigator at the time even voiced his doubts about this being a hit and run.

utterances.speaker: TROOPER TODD PROCTOR, SOUTH CAROLINA HIGHWAY PATROL
utterances.sentences: Typically you don't see the Highway Patrol working a murder. And that's what this is.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: That was the lead investigator at the time. Yet you still don't have answers and you still don't know who did this.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: MATNEY
utterances.sentences: This is either an extreme amount of corruption from very powerful people, who were able to pull all of these strings, or everybody involved in this did not do their job. And that is very scary for the justice system, too. Both sides, it's scary.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: What do you believe happened to your son, Stephen?

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: I feel like they beat him to death because the only damage was to his head. And he did have some defense wounds. He had a dislocated shoulder. It had to be somebody he knew to put his body like he was walking home.

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: I mean, my heart goes out to her. This is hard to believe.KAYE (voice-over):  It's been seven years and Stephen's case is still unsolved. His mother's attorney has yet to bring a case against the Murdaugh family.

utterances.speaker: HEMLEPP
utterances.sentences: There's no fact that I can point to, other than talk, rumors, speculation and the connection of SLED reopening the case at Moselle. There's nothing connected to the Murdaughs. And I'll tell you the other thing, there are people right now in Hampton, who know what happened. And they need to come forward.

utterances.speaker: MATNEY
utterances.sentences: Sandy lost her son but she also lost her own community because people were just turning their back, saying, we can't say anything.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: I want justice for my son.

utterances.speaker: JINKS
utterances.sentences: You deserve it.

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: You deserve it. You do.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: That's all I want.

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: You'll get it.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes. One step closer.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Mr. Murdaugh --KAYE (voice-over):  When we return --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I didn't think that they were interlaced.

utterances.speaker: JINKS
utterances.sentences: He forged my name.KAYE (voice-over):  We review some of the 90 financial fraud charges Alex Murdaugh is facing.

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: To learn that he used Gloria's death to enrich himself is horrible.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: 9-1-1, where's your emergency?KAYE (voice-over):  And later --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We were in a boat crash.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: The tragic death of 19-year-old Mallory Beach.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Tell me about Gloria.

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: Oh, Gloria was special. You know, everyone referred to her as the Murdaugh's housekeeper. She was more than that. She was a sister. She was a mother. She was loved by all of us.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: 9-1-1, where's your emergency?M. MURDAUGH:  My housekeeper has fallen and her head is bleeding. I cannot get her up. KAYE (voice-over):  According to Alex Murdaugh, in February of 2018, Gloria was picking up a check at his home when the Murdaugh's four dogs tripped her and she fell down their front porch steps. PAUL MURDAUGH, ALEX MURDAUGH'S SON:  I believe she maybe hit her head and maybe has a concussion or something.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: OK.Do you know what her name is? P. MURDAUGH:  Gloria Satterfield. KAYE (voice-over):  She died three weeks later.

utterances.speaker: BLAND
utterances.sentences: Maggie called Alex first.KAYE (voice-over):  Eric Bland represents Gloria Satterfield's estate.

utterances.speaker: BLAND
utterances.sentences: He said that he booked it home from work. Gloria was bleeding. And she told him, the dogs tripped me. And so he said she blacked out after that.

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: We all went to the hospital. Alex didn't come to the hospital. And nobody else came the whole entire time she was there, the three weeks.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: You don't believe your sister was killed?

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: It was murder. No, no. We still think it was an accident.KAYE (voice-over):  Ginger doesn't believe Alex Murdaugh killed her sister. But he is liable for another nefarious act in connection with her death.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: You discovered this insurance document related to the Gloria Satterfield case at some point.

utterances.speaker: MATNEY
utterances.sentences: I remember turning to Liz and being like, a curse word or two.

utterances.speaker: FARRELL
utterances.sentences: Right.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: MATNEY
utterances.sentences: Well, my god, whoa.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: And there was a settlement.KAYE (voice-over):  Alex Murdaugh, along with another attorney, had devised a scheme to sue his insurance company for the death of Gloria Satterfield, promising to give the money to Gloria's two surviving sons. The sons never saw what totaled to be $4.3 million. TONY SATTERFIELD, GLORIA'S SON:  Y'all, my name is Tony, you know, one of Gloria's younger sons.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: So when you think about your sister, Gloria's, loyalty to the Murdaugh family and to Alex Murdaugh and now you know he defrauded her sons $4.3 million ...

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: Yes, because they never got a dime.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: -- what do you make of that?

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: To learn that he used Gloria's death to enrich himself is horrible.

utterances.speaker: SPOHN
utterances.sentences: It's a heartbreaking --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Very heartbreaking.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Ruthless.

utterances.speaker: JINKS
utterances.sentences: Ruthless is the word for it.

utterances.speaker: BAMBERG
utterances.sentences: People wonder, how did they go and Ms. Gloria died and they steal all the money?Well, they had practice.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: What did happen to Hakeem Pinckney and why is he so central to this saga?

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: He had a settlement and then he just chose to not pay it to Hakeem's family --

utterances.speaker: BAMBERG
utterances.sentences: So --

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: -- allegedly.

utterances.speaker: BAMBERG
utterances.sentences: -- well, there ain't no allegedly. This is what happened. There -- some of the money went where it was supposed to go. And a large portion of it didn't, approximately $1 million.KAYE (voice-over):  Alex Murdaugh's alleged accomplice was Russell Laffitte, the former CEO of Palmetto State Bank. Murdaugh allegedly convinced the Pinckney family to hire Laffitte as their conservator and then funneled the money through the bank back to himself, a scheme they allegedly also concocted with Alaynia Spohn.

utterances.speaker: SPOHN
utterances.sentences: We were on I-95, coming through Hampton County. And a Firestone Bridgestone tire blew out and -- which caused our collision.

utterances.speaker: BLAND
utterances.sentences: Mother dies instantly, brother dies instantly.KAYE (voice-over):  Eric Bland is Alaynia's attorney.

utterances.speaker: BLAND
utterances.sentences: Alaynia is pinned in the back of the car. You're talking, in 2009, the case was settled for $9 million. I mean, huge settlement. And so they have to have somebody to help them manage their money.KAYE (voice-over):  Russell Laffitte was the conservator for Alaynia and her younger sister.

utterances.speaker: BLAND
utterances.sentences: Over the course of them being 11 and 18 years old, as a conservator, he loaned money to himself and to Alex Murdaugh from a conservatorship account. He loaned himself over $600,000. He loaned over $800,000 to Alex Murdaugh. And these girls would get NSF checks come back to them --

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Not sufficient funds.

utterances.speaker: BLAND
utterances.sentences: -- not sufficient funds because he had spent all the money.

utterances.speaker: SPOHN
utterances.sentences: I remember him telling me, like, these people took your mom and your brother, because of their mistake. So we're going to make it right and you're not going to have to work another day in your life. And knowing that, like, I'm over here pinching pennies.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Because he was limiting your funds.

utterances.speaker: SPOHN
utterances.sentences: Yes. Oh, yes, definitely.

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: I think, yes. This is horrible. It's a horrible thought. You got kids that are in need and scared to even ask to get money to buy something they need. And here they are, they are just spending it like it's nothing. JINKSKAYE (voice-over):  Jordan Jinks is Alex's childhood friend.

utterances.speaker: JINKS
utterances.sentences: I had a car accident. I was rear-ended by a pool company out of Hilton Head. So I called Alex. That was the first person I called.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: And Alex Murdaugh got a settlement for you.

utterances.speaker: JINKS
utterances.sentences: Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: And that money came right to you?

utterances.speaker: JINKS
utterances.sentences: Not all of it.KAYE (voice-over):  Alex Murdaugh allegedly defrauded Jordan Jinks of $150,000.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: He was a friend.

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: And he convinced you that he's working for you and doing everything above and beyond for you.

utterances.speaker: JINKS
utterances.sentences: I trusted Alex like a brother. Alex and I ate off the same plate.

utterances.speaker: SPOHN
utterances.sentences: If he is willing to do that to a childhood friend, he'll do it to anyone.KAYE (voice-over):  Russell Laffitte was convicted on six counts of financial fraud crimes by a federal jury in November of 2022. All of the charges were related to Murdaugh steal from their mutual clients. Each one holds a maximum sentence of up to 30 years in prison. Their lawyers did not respond to a request for comment about these financial fraud charges.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Why did you kill your wife?KAYE (voice-over):  When we return --

utterances.speaker: MONK
utterances.sentences: This trial will probably be one of the most watched since O.J.KAYE (voice-over):  What happens next?

utterances.speaker: CONNOR COOK, BOAT PASSENGER
utterances.sentences: What bridge?Paul, what bridge is this?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: 9-1-1, where's your emergency?

utterances.speaker: COOK
utterances.sentences: We're in a boat crash on Archers Creek. We have someone missing.KAYE (voice-over):  In February of 2019, 19-year-old Mallory Beach was killed while boating with five other friends, including Alex Murdaugh's youngest son, Paul. Paul was allegedly driving the boat intoxicated and crashed. Mallory's body was found eight days later.

utterances.speaker: MATNEY
utterances.sentences: We knew that the accused driver, from what everybody in Hampton was saying, was Paul Murdaugh and who also happens to have all these influences around local cops.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Hey, buddy.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: You want to get checked out by the ambulance?P. MURDAUGH:  Yes, I'm fine.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Sure?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Let's get you checked out, all right?P. MURDAUGH:  Yes, I'm fine.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: What's your last name. buddy?P. MURDAUGH:  Murdaugh.

utterances.speaker: MATNEY
utterances.sentences: We kept asking for the initial police report, the incident report from DNR. And we didn't get -- I didn't get that until 2021. And that is so odd to me. Usually you can always get an incident report.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: So you were suspicious, right?

utterances.speaker: MATNEY
utterances.sentences: Very suspicious. Everything was suspicious.

utterances.speaker: FARRELL
utterances.sentences: Well, we had good sources in law enforcement. And they told us, you know, the fix is in already.KAYE (voice-over):  In the incident report, law enforcement did not specify who was driving the boat. Joe McCulloch represents Connor Cook, one of the surviving passengers.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: What happened at the hospital?

utterances.speaker: MCCULLOCH
utterances.sentences: There was an effort by the Murdaugh family to influence those young people, their parents, to influence law enforcement.

utterances.speaker: BLAND
utterances.sentences: How does Alex (sic) get to go to the accident scene with his father and start to direct people around like that?It doesn't happen anywhere else.

utterances.speaker: HEMLEPP
utterances.sentences: It was the hubris and the privilege.KAYE (voice-over):  Paul Murdaugh was eventually indicted and charged with boating under the influence, resulting in death. But Paul would never face trial. He and his mother, Maggie Murdaugh, were killed nearly 2.5 years after the boating accident. Three months after the double homicide --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Hampton County 9-1-1, what's your emergency?KAYE (voice-over):  Alex Murdaugh claimed someone tried to kill him, too. A. MURDAUGH:  I got a flat tire and I stopped and somebody stopped to help me. And when I turned my back, they tried to shoot me.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Oh, OK.Were you shot? A. MURDAUGH:  Yes, but I'm OK. KAYE (voice-over):  His lawyers later admitted in court it was a fake suicide attempt.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: He admits that he was just trying to do this to get this $10 million in life insurance for his now only surviving son, Buster.So do you buy that, that the motive was to -- he was looking out for his son?

utterances.speaker: BLAND
utterances.sentences: No, he was just trying to divert the attention away from him. (CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: BAMBERG
utterances.sentences: I think this --

utterances.speaker: MCCULLOCH
utterances.sentences: From the get-go, it was a ploy to promote, the ninja warriors are after me.

utterances.speaker: BAMBERG
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: So there's this life insurance policy and then this alleged opioid addiction. Attorneys for him said, for the last 20 years, there have been many people feeding his addiction to opioids. Alex is not without fault but he is just one of many whose life has been devastated by opioid addiction.So what do you make of that statement, Mike? (LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: BLAND
utterances.sentences: Can you talk?

utterances.speaker: BAMBERG
utterances.sentences: His face says it's all.

utterances.speaker: HEMLEPP
utterances.sentences: It's hard when you're on TV to respond to that.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: We can bleep, whatever.

utterances.speaker: HEMLEPP
utterances.sentences: This is all bullshit. It's all bullshit.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: Was there ever any sign that he used opioids?

utterances.speaker: JINKS
utterances.sentences: Hmm, yes and no. Before stuff started happening, I would have went to his defense, 200 percent.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: And now with all this, you think he had to be on some sort of stuff?(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: JINKS
utterances.sentences: Had to be. Had to be.KAYE (voice-over):  Alex Murdaugh's double murder trial for Maggie and Paul began on January 23rd. It's expected to last a few weeks.

utterances.speaker: CREIGHTON WATERS, STATE CHIEF PROSECUTOR
utterances.sentences: With two shots to the head ...KAYE (voice-over):  So far, prosecutor Creighton Waters attempted early on to convince the jury Alex Murdaugh was at the scene when Paul and Maggie were killed, despite him saying he wasn't.

utterances.speaker: WATERS
utterances.sentences: At 8

utterances.speaker: DICK HARPOOTLIAN, DEFENSE ATTORNEY
utterances.sentences: His head exploded. You would be covered in blood from head to foot.KAYE (voice-over):  Alex Murdaugh told investigators that he tried to check the pulse on both his wife, Maggie, and son, Paul. Yet Alex didn't appear to have any blood on him, this investigator told the court.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Did you see anything that appeared to be blood on his shoe?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I did not.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Did you see what appeared to be blood on Alex Murdaugh's hands?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: I did not.KAYE (voice-over):  And when the defense lawyer asked her why she thought his clothes were freshly washed ...

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: He's sweating and they're dry, so I would say yes.KAYE (voice-over):  Still, on cross examination, the defense tried to poke holes in the idea that Alex Murdaugh may have washed his clothes after allegedly killing his wife and son.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Well, let me ask you, in your mind's eye, that night, on June 7th, did he look like someone who had just blown his son's head off, spattering blood everywhere?

utterances.speaker: MONK
utterances.sentences: This trial will probably be one of the most watched since O.J.KAYE (voice-over):  Murdaugh's trial in connection to Mallory Beach's wrongful death lawsuit has yet to be scheduled. SLED did open a new investigation into Gloria Satterfield's death, the Murdaugh's housekeeper, and planned to exhume her body. Alex Murdaugh has admitted in court to stealing the insurance settlement funds that belonged to Gloria's estate. And as for Stephen Smith, his case has been reopened.

utterances.speaker: KAYE
utterances.sentences: What are your thoughts on the public perception of this county, now that the Murdaugh name is out there and the case is getting national attention?I mean, what do you think people think of this county and this place where you grew up?

utterances.speaker: JINKS
utterances.sentences: You go ahead.(LAUGHTER)

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Well, a lot of people ask me, it's just, they can't believe that such a small community, that people didn't know that this stuff was going on in their county. And, of course, we have no clue what was going on, because they were hiding, because it was that one group of people who were working together.

utterances.speaker: HADWIN
utterances.sentences: To us, it's still home, you know.

utterances.speaker: JINKS
utterances.sentences: I think this bad thing is going to be a great thing for Hampton County.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: JINKS
utterances.sentences: Because of the chokehold, the power that they had over Hampton County, there's a great hope that Hampton County will start its blossoms.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: JINKS
utterances.sentences: Because of this.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: Because now that power is --

utterances.speaker: JINKS
utterances.sentences: That power is diminished.

utterances.speaker: SMITH
utterances.sentences: No longer in control.
